title: Ep. 6 What is Life?:  Time, a One-Way Sign that Enables Computation as Entropy Enables Creativity
description:
Scroll to the end of the notes for the links Glen referred to.
Notes on our talk:  Karen and Glen continue to pursue the nature of life, tightening up a definition of entropy and exploring computational theory and emergence and the underlying implications of each.

The exciting points in physics are when things don't fit, when anomalies show up, because that indicates a new physics is needed.
Entropy is more qualitative than quantitative.
You can't have creativity without entropy. It takes excess energy to get things over the hump. It takes energy too create order and to maintain order.
You can only play the deconstruction game once.
Irreversibility is a fundamental aspect of the universe. All the science silos have their own definitions of and formulas for entropy, but they all have one thing in common. The universe is fundamentally irreversible. The 2nd law is not driving time but is a consequence of that.
The laws of physics appear to be reversible, but is that just a function of the continuous and differentiable functions that physics is using to do the calculations? 
Physics is always creating mathematical models that describe what we see in the universe around us, not what it is actually doing.

Computation:  the simplest system is a finite state machine. The memory of the past is gone. Shows irreversibility in computation. Landauer's principle, Landauer's eraser.
When you go through a logic gate, you lose information and entropy has gone up.
Transistors need to be in a very specific order to be useful. 
Emergence crosses a barrier when something complicated becomes simple again. The inside v. the outside view.
Hilbert's decidability challenge. Turing worked to find out which problems are undecidable no matter how long the calculation runs.
The universe is putting new information into the system. Layers of emergence, the nested nature of systems - implies other layers above us.
The challenge is to create a system that can adjust moment by moment to its environment.
Emergence:  starting from simple rules, you can create something that is undecidable. Computation turns information into energy. Ideas have a physical existence.
Turing asked deep questions about what it means to be human.
Philip Clayton's book, Re-emergence of Emergence is linked below. Will discuss next time.
Does God know the future? Does God forget?

One of the better popular science video channels that tries to tackle the deeper questions in physics. “PBS Space-Time,”  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7_gcs09iThXybpVgjHZ_7g
 
From my point of view the best nontechnical introduction to Turing machines. “Turing machines explained visually, (8:45-duration)” https://youtu.be/-ZS_zFg4w5k
 
It might help in understanding how Turing machines work to see one in actual operation. People have constructed them in many different ways, including using LEGO’s. “LEGO Turing Machine, (2:22-duration)” https://youtu.be/FTSAiF9AHN4
 
While only a short clip was taken from this YouTube link, the complete interview is well worth listening to. “Computers Without Memory – Computerphile, (8:51-duration)” https://youtu.be/vhiiia1_hC4
 
The short presentation with George Ellis was taken from this fuller YouTube link. “Understanding Consciousness | Rupert Sheldrake, George Ellis, Amie Thomasson, (43:40-duration)” https://youtu.be/c-QOlTD0YHo
 
No doubt the best source of introductory interviews on the question of Emergence can be found here. Over the years the narrator Robert Kuhn has managed to interview all of the leading minds on the subject of Emergence. Most of the interview segments are short, 10 minutes, give or take. But in total, there are many hours-worth of individual interviews posted here. “Closer to Truth, the PBS/public television series on cosmos, consciousness and meaning…,” https://www.closertotruth.com/search/site/emergence
 
And for those who are more book oriented, and have had no previous exposure to the subject of Emergence, this collection of essays would be an excellent place to start. “The Re-Emergence of Emergence: The Emergentist Hypothesis from Science to Religion,” https://www.amazon.com/Re-Emergence-Emergence-Emergentist-Hypothesis-Religion/dp/019954431X
 
Homework for next time: from one of the authors of the above work, Phillip Clayton, here’s the real bombshell that the physics of Emergence throws into theology, link to https://www.closertotruth.com/series/why-emergence-significant and listen to his segment posted there.
 
/************/
 
For the actual interview, these are the two clips with duration that I was referring to.
 
Play from time stamp 4:17 to 5:05…
“Computers Without Memory – Computerphile,” https://youtu.be/vhiiia1_hC4?t=256
 
Play from time stamp 0:05 to 1:35…
“What Exists is Not Only Physical | George Ellis,”  https://youtu.be/Zx3F73po4YE?t=5

Whole 6 Part series Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoARw9zo4EUZhxqfaqYU5yjy0-Tr8RlB4
